title: Birmingham to stick by Gianfranco Zola - but believe he could QUIT if beaten by Wolves
text:
Birmingham to stick by Gianfranco Zola - but believe he could QUIT if beaten by Wolves The Italian has won only won of his 14 games in charge of the Blues, ahead of Friday's Midlands derby at Molineux Share Comments By John Wragg 22:30, 19 FEB 2017 Sport Zola is under pressure at St Andrews (Photo: Getty Images Europe) football Gianfranco Zola could quit Birmingham City if his side collapses to another big defeat in Friday’s local derby at Wolves.
Zola cut a depressed, worried figure after Blues were hammered 4-1 at home to QPR.
It leaves the Italian with only one win in 14 games since the shock sacking of Gary Rowett.
Zola has earned just six points out of 12 Championship games and went out of the FA Cup in a replay at Newcastle.
Chinese owner Paul Suen was the man who brought in Zola four months ago and will back him rather than lose face.
Things haven't gone to plan under the Italian (Photo: Gareth Copley) Zola's side were thumped 4-1 by QPR (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) There were six key players missing through injury and suspension for the QPR game and the board expects better when most of them are back against Wolves.
The decision will be Zola’s and the feeling inside the club is that he is an honourable man who will resign if he feels he cannot be successful.
Zola’s only win was at home to Fulham and before that game club directors took him out for a meal to reassure him his job was safe.
That is still the case and no emergency talks are planned. He would only be sacked if the wheels totally came off at Wolves and then home to Leeds.
Gary Rowett was surprisingly sacked (Photo: Action Images) Gianfranco Zola is unveiled as Birmingham City's new manager Zola was recognised as a great player at Chelsea, winning the European Cup Winners’ Cup, two FA Cups and the League Cup in seven years.
But his managerial career is patchy with a losing Championship play-off final at Watford his highlight.
Zola is a popular hard working figure at Birmingham and has been tasked with building an attractive, successful team.
“I feel that I have to give more to the players,” says Zola.
“It is difficult for me to justify all that has happened. We need to work hard and find solutions because these Birmingham fans deserve it.”
Ian Holloway had his say on things at St Andrews (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) QPR boss Ian Holloway questioned the Birmingham board’s decision making.
“The last Birmingham manager did absolutely fantastic. Unfortunately the work you do some times doesn’t get recognised,” said Holloway. “It certainly is by the fans and they don’t know what to think at the moment.
“Your club doesn’t belong to you I’m afraid, it belongs to someone who buys it and they’ve got carte blanche to do whatever they want.
“We went six games without a win, but QPR fans know me and Les Ferdinand knows me.
“But Birmingham fans won’t know anything about Mr Zola. Looking where they were in the table, why did you need to make a change?”
